title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Setup

library(tidyverse)

bikes <- readr::read_csv(
  "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/z3tt/graphic-design-ggplot2/main/data/london-bikes-custom.csv", 
  col_types = "Dcfffilllddddc"
)

bikes$season <- forcats::fct_inorder(bikes$season)

theme_set(theme_light(base_size = 14, base_family = "Roboto Condensed"))

theme_update(
  panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
  plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"),
  legend.position = "top",
  plot.title.position = "plot"
)

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Facets

= split variables to multiple panels

Facets are also known as:

small multiples
trellis graphs
lattice plots
conditioning

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Setup


g <-
  ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = temp_feel, y = count,
        color = season)
  ) +
  geom_point(
    alpha = .3,
    guide = "none"
  )

g

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Wrapped Facet


g +
  facet_wrap(
    vars(day_night)
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Wrapped Facet


g +
  facet_wrap(
    ~ day_night
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Facet Multiple Variables


g +
  facet_wrap(
    ~ is_workday + day_night
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Facet Options: Cols + Rows


g +
  facet_wrap(
    ~ day_night,
    ncol = 1
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Facet Options: Free Scaling


g +
  facet_wrap(
    ~ day_night,
    ncol = 1,
    scales = "free"
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Facet Options: Free Scaling


g +
  facet_wrap(
    ~ day_night,
    ncol = 1,
    scales = "free_y"
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Facet Options: Switch Labels


g +
  facet_wrap(
    ~ day_night,
    ncol = 1,
    switch = "x"
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Gridded Facet


g +
  facet_grid(
    rows = vars(day_night), 
    cols = vars(is_workday)
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Gridded Facet


g +
  facet_grid(
    day_night ~ is_workday
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Facet Multiple Variables


g +
  facet_grid(
    day_night ~ is_workday + season
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Facet Options: Free Scaling


g +
  facet_grid(
    day_night ~ is_workday,
    scales = "free"
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Facet Options: Switch Labels


g +
  facet_grid(
    day_night ~ is_workday,
    scales = "free",
    switch = "y"
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Facet Options: Proportional Spacing


g +
  facet_grid(
    day_night ~ is_workday,
    scales = "free",
    space = "free"
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Facet Options: Proportional Spacing


g +
  facet_grid(
    day_night ~ is_workday,
    scales = "free_y",
    space = "free_y"
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Your Turn!

Create the following facet from the diamonds data.

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Quick Exercise

Bonus: Create this bloody-dark version.

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Diamonds Facet


ggplot(
    diamonds, 
    aes(x = carat, y = price)
  ) +
  geom_point(
    alpha = .3
  ) +
  geom_smooth(
    method = "lm", 
    se = FALSE, 
    color = "dodgerblue"
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Diamonds Facet


ggplot(
    diamonds, 
    aes(x = carat, y = price)
  ) +
  geom_point(
    alpha = .3
  ) +
  geom_smooth(
    method = "lm", 
    se = FALSE, 
    color = "dodgerblue"
  ) +
  facet_grid(
    cut ~ clarity, 
    space = "free_x", 
    scales = "free_x"
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Diamonds Facet (Dark Theme Bonus)


ggplot(
    diamonds, 
    aes(x = carat, y = price)
  ) +
  geom_point(
    alpha = .3,
    color = "white"
  ) +
  geom_smooth(
    method = "lm", 
    se = FALSE, 
    color = "dodgerblue"
  ) +
  facet_grid(
    cut ~ clarity, 
    space = "free_x", 
    scales = "free_x"
  ) +
  theme_dark(
    base_size = 14,
    base_family = "Roboto Condensed"
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Scales

= translate between variable ranges and property ranges


feels-like temperature  ⇄  x
reported bike shares  ⇄  y
season  ⇄  color
year  ⇄  shape
…

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Scales
The scale_*() components control the properties of all theaesthetic dimensions mapped to the data.
Consequently, there are scale_*() functions for all aesthetics such as:

positions via scale_x_*() and scale_y_*()
colors via scale_color_*() and scale_fill_*()
sizes via scale_size_*() and scale_radius_*()
shapes via scale_shape_*() and scale_linetype_*()
transparency via scale_alpha_*()

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Scales
The scale_*() components control the properties of all theaesthetic dimensions mapped to the data.
The extensions (*) can be filled by e.g.:

continuous(), discrete(), reverse(), log10(), sqrt(), date() for positions
continuous(), discrete(), manual(), gradient(), gradient2(), brewer() for colors
continuous(), discrete(), manual(), ordinal(), area(), date() for sizes
continuous(), discrete(), manual(), ordinal() for shapes
continuous(), discrete(), manual(), ordinal(), date() for transparency

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Continuous vs. Discrete in {ggplot2}



Continuous:quantitative or numerical data

height
weight
age
counts



Discrete:qualitative or categorical data

species
sex
study sites
age group

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Continuous vs. Discrete in {ggplot2}



Continuous:quantitative or numerical data

height (continuous)
weight (continuous)
age (continuous or discrete)
counts (discrete)



Discrete:qualitative or categorical data

species (nominal)
sex (nominal)
study site (nominal or ordinal)
age group (ordinal)

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Aesthetics + Scales


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = date, y = count,
        color = season)
  ) +
  geom_point()

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Aesthetics + Scales


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = date, y = count,
        color = season)
  ) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_x_date() +
  scale_y_continuous() +
  scale_color_discrete()

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Scales


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = date, y = count,
        color = season)
  ) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_x_continuous() +
  scale_y_continuous() +
  scale_color_discrete()

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Scales


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = date, y = count,
        color = season)
  ) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_x_continuous() +
  scale_y_log10() +
  scale_color_discrete()

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Scales


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = date, y = count,
        color = season)
  ) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_x_continuous() +
  scale_y_log10() +
  scale_color_viridis_d()

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
`scale_x|y_continuous`


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = date, y = count,
        color = season)
  ) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_x_date() +
  scale_y_continuous(
    trans = "log10"
  ) +
  scale_color_discrete()

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
`scale_x|y_continuous`


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = date, y = count,
        color = season)
  ) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_x_date() +
  scale_y_continuous(
    name = "Reported bike shares"
  ) +
  scale_color_discrete()

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
`scale_x|y_continuous`


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = date, y = count,
        color = season)
  ) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_x_date() +
  scale_y_continuous(
    name = "Reported bike shares",
    breaks = seq(0, 60000, by = 15000)
  ) +
  scale_color_discrete()

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
`scale_x|y_continuous`


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = date, y = count,
        color = season)
  ) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_x_date() +
  scale_y_continuous(
    name = "Reported bike shares",
    breaks = 0:4*15000
  ) +
  scale_color_discrete()

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
`scale_x|y_continuous`


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = date, y = count,
        color = season)
  ) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_x_date() +
  scale_y_continuous(
    name = "Reported bike shares",
    breaks = c(0, seq(5000, 30000, by = 2500), 40000, 50000)
  ) +
  scale_color_discrete()

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
`scale_x|y_continuous`


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = date, y = count,
        color = season)
  ) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_x_date() +
  scale_y_continuous(
    name = "Reported bike shares in thousands",
    breaks = 0:4*15000,
    labels = 0:4*15
  ) +
  scale_color_discrete()

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
`scale_x|y_continuous`


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = date, y = count,
        color = season)
  ) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_x_date() +
  scale_y_continuous(
    name = "Reported bike shares in thousands",
    breaks = 0:4,
    labels = paste(0:4*15000, "bikes")
  ) +
  scale_color_discrete()

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
`scale_x|y_continuous`


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = date, y = count,
        color = season)
  ) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_x_date() +
  scale_y_continuous(
    name = "Reported bike shares",
    breaks = 0:4*15000,
    limits = c(NA, 60000)
  ) +
  scale_color_discrete()

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
`scale_x|y_continuous`


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = date, y = count,
        color = season)
  ) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_x_date() +
  scale_y_continuous(
    name = "Reported bike shares",
    breaks = 0:4*15000,
    expand = c(0, 0)
  ) +
  scale_color_discrete()

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
`scale_x|y_continuous`


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = date, y = count,
        color = season)
  ) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_x_date() +
  scale_y_continuous(
    name = "Reported bike shares",
    breaks = -1:5*15000,
    expand = c(.5, .5)
  ) +
  scale_color_discrete()

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
`scale_x|y_continuous`


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = date, y = count,
        color = season)
  ) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_y_continuous(
    name = "Reported bike shares",
    breaks = 0:4*15000,
    guide = "none"
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
`scale_x|y_date`


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = date, y = count,
        color = season)
  ) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_x_date(
    name = NULL,
    date_breaks = "3 months"
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
`scale_x|y_date`


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = date, y = count,
        color = season)
  ) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_x_date(
    name = NULL,
    date_breaks = "20 weeks"
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
`scale_x|y_date` with `strftime()`


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = date, y = count,
        color = season)
  ) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_x_date(
    name = NULL,
    date_breaks = "4 months",
    date_labels = "%Y/%m/%d"
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
`scale_x|y_date` with `strftime()`


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = date, y = count)
  ) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_x_date(
    name = NULL,
    date_breaks = "4 months",
    date_labels = "%b '%y"
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
`scale_x|y_discrete`


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = season, y = count)
  ) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  scale_x_discrete(
    name = "Period",
    labels = c("Dec-Feb", "Mar-May", "Jun-Aug", "Sep-Nov")
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
`scale_x|y_discrete`


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = season, y = count)
  ) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  scale_x_discrete(
    name = "Season",
    expand = c(.5, .5)
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Discrete or Continuous?


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = as.numeric(season), y = count)
  ) +
  geom_boxplot(
    aes(group = season)
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Discrete or Continuous?


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = as.numeric(season), 
        y = count)
  ) +
  geom_boxplot(
    aes(group = season)
  ) +
  scale_x_continuous(
    name = "Season",
    breaks = 1:4,
    labels = levels(bikes$season)
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Discrete or Continuous?


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = as.numeric(season) + as.numeric(season) / 8, 
        y = count)
  ) +
  geom_boxplot(
    aes(group = season)
  ) +
  scale_x_continuous(
    name = "Season",
    breaks = 1:4,
    labels = levels(bikes$season)
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
`scale_color|fill_discrete`


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = date, y = count,
        color = season)
  ) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_color_discrete(
    name = "Season:",
    type = c("#69b0d4", "#00CB79", "#F7B01B", "#a78f5f")
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Inspect Assigned Colors


g <- ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = date, y = count,
        color = season)
  ) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_color_discrete(
    name = "Season:",
    type = c("#69b0d4", "#00CB79", "#F7B01B", "#a78f5f")
  )

gb <- ggplot_build(g)

gb$data[[1]][1:10,]


    colour     x     y PANEL group shape size fill alpha stroke
1  #69b0d4 16439  6830     1     1    19  1.5   NA    NA    0.5
2  #69b0d4 16439  2404     1     1    19  1.5   NA    NA    0.5

5  #69b0d4 16441 14501     1     1    19  1.5   NA    NA    0.5
6  #69b0d4 16441  6112     1     1    19  1.5   NA    NA    0.5
7  #69b0d4 16442 16358     1     1    19  1.5   NA    NA    0.5
8  #69b0d4 16442  4706     1     1    19  1.5   NA    NA    0.5

10 #69b0d4 16443  5630     1     1    19  1.5   NA    NA    0.5

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
`scale_color|fill_discrete`


my_colors <- c(
  `winter` = "#69b0d4", 
  `spring` = "#00CB79", 
  `summer` = "#F7B01B", 
  `autumn` = "#a78f5f"
)

ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = date, y = count,
        color = season)
  ) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_color_discrete(
    name = "Season:",
    type = my_colors
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
`scale_color|fill_discrete`


my_colors_alphabetical <- c(
  `autumn` = "#a78f5f", 
  `spring` = "#00CB79", 
  `summer` = "#F7B01B", 
  `winter` = "#69b0d4"
)

ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = date, y = count,
        color = season)
  ) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_color_discrete(
    name = "Season:",
    type = my_colors_alphabetical
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
`scale_color|fill_discrete`


library(RColorBrewer)

ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = date, y = count,
        color = season)
  ) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_color_discrete(
    name = "Season:",
    type = brewer.pal(
      n = 4, name = "Dark2"
    )
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
`scale_color|fill_manual`


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = date, y = count,
        color = weather_type)
  ) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_color_manual(
    name = "Season:",
    values = brewer.pal(n = 6, name = "Pastel1"),
    na.value = "black"
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
`scale_color|fill_carto_d`


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = date, y = count,
        color = weather_type)
  ) +
  geom_point() +
  rcartocolor::scale_color_carto_d(
    name = "Season:",
    palette = "Pastel",
    na.value = "black" 
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Your Turn!

**Modify our dianmonds facet like this:

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Diamonds Facet


facet <- 
  ggplot(
    diamonds, 
    aes(x = carat, y = price)
  ) +
  geom_point(
    alpha = .3
  ) +
  geom_smooth(
    aes(color = cut),
    method = "lm", 
    se = FALSE
  ) +
  facet_grid(
    cut ~ clarity, 
    space = "free_x", 
    scales = "free_x"
  )

facet

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Diamonds Facet


facet +
  scale_x_continuous(
    breaks = 0:5
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(
    limits = c(0, 30000),
    breaks = 0:3*10000, 
    labels = c("$0", "$10,000", "$20,000", "$30,000")
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Diamonds Facet


facet +
  scale_x_continuous(
    breaks = 0:5
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(
    limits = c(0, 30000),
    breaks = 0:3*10000, 
    labels = paste0(
      "$", format(0:3*10000, big.mark = ",")
    )
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Diamonds Facet


facet +
  scale_x_continuous(
    breaks = 0:5
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(
    limits = c(0, 30000),
    breaks = 0:3*10000, 
    labels = function(y) paste0(
      "$", format(y, big.mark=",")
    )
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Diamonds Facet


facet +
  scale_x_continuous(
    breaks = 0:5
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(
    limits = c(0, 30000),
    breaks = 0:3*10000, 
    labels = scales::dollar_format()
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Diamonds Facet


facet +
  scale_x_continuous(
    breaks = 0:5
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(
    limits = c(0, 30000),
    breaks = 0:3*10000, 
    labels = scales::dollar_format()
  ) +
  scale_color_brewer(
    palette = "Set2",
    guide = "none"
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Diamonds Facet


facet +
  scale_x_continuous(
    breaks = 0:5
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(
    limits = c(0, 30000),
    breaks = 0:3*10000, 
    labels = scales::dollar_format()
  ) +
  scale_color_brewer(
    palette = "Set2"
  ) +
  theme(
    legend.position = "none"
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Coordinate Systems

= interpret the position aesthetics


linear coordinate systems:preserve the geometrical shapes

coord_cartesian()
coord_fixed()
coord_flip()

linear coordinate systems:likely change the geometrical shapes

coord_polar()
coord_map() and coord_sf()
coord_trans()

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Cartesian Coordinate System


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = season, y = count)
  ) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  coord_cartesian()

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Cartesian Coordinate System


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = season, y = count)
  ) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  coord_cartesian(
    ylim = c(NA, 15000) 
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Changing Limits



ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = season, y = count)
  ) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  coord_cartesian(
    ylim = c(NA, 15000) 
  )





ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = season, y = count)
  ) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  scale_y_continuous(
    limits = c(NA, 15000) 
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Clipping


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = season, y = count)
  ) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  coord_cartesian(
    ylim = c(NA, 15000),
    clip = "off"
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Clipping


ggplot(
    filter(bikes, is_holiday == TRUE), 
    aes(x = temp_feel, y = count)
  ) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_text(
    aes(label = season),
    nudge_x = .3,
    hjust = 0
  ) +
  coord_cartesian(
    clip = "off"
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
… or better use {ggrepel}


ggplot(
    filter(bikes, is_holiday == TRUE), 
    aes(x = temp_feel, y = count)
  ) +
  geom_point() +
  ggrepel::geom_text_repel(
    aes(label = season),
    nudge_x = .3,
    hjust = 0
  ) +
  coord_cartesian(
    clip = "off"
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Remove All Padding


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = temp_feel, y = count)
  ) +
  geom_point() +
  coord_cartesian(
    expand = FALSE,
    clip = "off"
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Fixed Coordinate System



ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = temp_feel, y = temp)
  ) +
  geom_point() +
  coord_fixed()






ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = temp_feel, y = temp)
  ) +
  geom_point() +
  coord_fixed(ratio = 4)

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Flipped Coordinate System



ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = weather_type)
  ) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_cartesian()






ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = weather_type)
  ) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip()

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Flipped Coordinate System



ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(y = weather_type)
  ) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_cartesian()






ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = weather_type)
  ) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip()

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Reminder: Sort Your Bars!


ggplot(
    filter(bikes, !is.na(weather_type)), 
    aes(y = fct_infreq(weather_type))
  ) +
  geom_bar()

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Reminder: Sort Your Bars!


ggplot(
    filter(bikes, !is.na(weather_type)), 
    aes(y = fct_rev(
      fct_infreq(weather_type)
    ))
  ) +
  geom_bar()

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Circular Corrdinate System



ggplot(
    filter(bikes, !is.na(weather_type)), 
    aes(x = weather_type,
        fill = weather_type)
  ) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_polar()






ggplot(
    filter(bikes, !is.na(weather_type)), 
    aes(x = weather_type,
        fill = weather_type)
  ) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_cartesian()

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Circular Corrdinate System



ggplot(
    filter(bikes, !is.na(weather_type)), 
    aes(x = fct_infreq(weather_type),
        fill = weather_type)
  ) +
  geom_bar(width = 1) +
  coord_polar()





ggplot(
    filter(bikes, !is.na(weather_type)), 
    aes(x = fct_infreq(weather_type),
        fill = weather_type)
  ) +
  geom_bar(width = 1) +
  coord_cartesian()

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Circular Corrdinate System



ggplot(
    filter(bikes, !is.na(weather_type)), 
    aes(x = fct_infreq(weather_type),
        fill = weather_type)
  ) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_polar(theta = "x")






ggplot(
    filter(bikes, !is.na(weather_type)), 
    aes(x = fct_infreq(weather_type),
        fill = weather_type)
  ) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_polar(theta = "y")

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Circular Corrdinate System



ggplot(
    filter(bikes, !is.na(weather_type)), 
    aes(x = 1,
        fill = fct_rev(fct_infreq(weather_type)))
  ) +
  geom_bar(position = "stack") +
  coord_polar(theta = "y")






ggplot(
    filter(bikes, !is.na(weather_type)), 
    aes(x = 1,
        fill = fct_rev(fct_infreq(weather_type)))
  ) +
  geom_bar(position = "stack") +
  coord_cartesian()

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Transform a Coordinate System


ggplot(
    bikes,
    aes(x = temp, y = count)
  ) +
  geom_point() +
  coord_trans(y = "log10")

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Transform a Coordinate System



ggplot(
    bikes,
    aes(x = temp, y = count,
        group = day_night)
  ) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm") +
  coord_trans(y = "log10")






ggplot(
    bikes,
    aes(x = temp, y = count,
        group = day_night)
  ) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm") +
  scale_y_log10()

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Spatial Coordinate (Reference) Systems


countries <- rnaturalearth::ne_countries(
  returnclass = "sf"
)

ggplot() +
  geom_sf(
    data = countries, 
    color = "#79dfbd",
    fill = "#28a87d",
    size = .3
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Spatial Coordinate (Reference) Systems


ggplot() +
  geom_sf(
    data = countries, 
    color = "#79dfbd",
    fill = "#28a87d",
    size = .3
  ) +
  coord_sf(
    crs = "+proj=moll"
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Spatial Coordinate (Reference) Systems


ggplot() +
  geom_sf(
    data = countries, 
    color = "#79dfbd",
    fill = "#28a87d",
    size = .3
  ) +
  coord_sf(
    crs = "+proj=bonne +lat_1=10"
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Spatial Coordinate (Reference) Systems


oceans <- rnaturalearth::ne_download(
  category = "physical", type = "ocean", returnclass = "sf"
)


OGR data source with driver: ESRI Shapefile 
Source: "/private/var/folders/md/ms6zrv3d6rd4506k3hd7dt140000gn/T/RtmpPW1V35", layer: "ne_110m_ocean"
with 2 features
It has 3 fields

ggplot() +
  geom_sf(
    data = oceans,
    fill = "#d8f1f6"
  ) +
  geom_sf(
    data = countries, 
    color = "#79dfbd",
    fill = "#28a87d",
    size = .3
  ) +
  coord_sf(
    crs = "+proj=bonne +lat_1=10"
  ) +
  theme_void()

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Recap



facet_*() functions allow to create small multiples
scale_*() functions translate between aesthetics and properties
use *_continuous() for numerical data
… and *_discrete() for categorical data
use scale_color|fill_*() to customize data-related colors
coord_*() functions interpret the positional aesthetics
be careful when adjusting axis limits:

scale_*_continuous(limits) removes the data outside the range
coord_*(*lim) keeps the data and zooms into the range

{ggplot2} + {sf} are a powerful duo to create maps in R

10:00

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Communication Strategy



Green sticky note — I am done with the exercise
Pink sticky note — I need help or support
You can ask questions / comment at any time during the course.
Please avoid questions during the breaks to give us a chance to recover and reflect.
Team up with your neighbors for exercises — and lunch!
We will collect feedback twice during the day (more later).

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
{ggplot2} package description



{ggplot2} is a system for declaratively creating graphics,based on “The Grammar of Graphics” (Wilkinson, 2005).

You provide the data, tell {ggplot2} how tomap variables to aesthetics,what graphical primitives to use, and it takes care of the details.

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Advantages of {ggplot2}


consistent underlying “grammar of graphics” (Wilkinson 2005)

very flexible, layered plot specification

theme system for polishing plot appearance

lots of additional functionality thanks to extensions

active and helpful community

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
The ggplot2 Package

… is an R package to visualize data created by Hadley Wickham in 2005

# install.packages("ggplot2")
library(ggplot2)



… is part of the {tidyverse}

# install.packages("tidyverse")
library(tidyverse)

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
The Grammar of {ggplot2}





Component


Function


Explanation




Data


ggplot(data)         


The raw data that you want to visualise.




Aesthetics          


aes()


Aesthetic mappings between variables and visual properties..



Geometries


geom_*()


The geometric shapes representing the data.

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
The Grammar of {ggplot2}





Component


Function


Explanation




Data


ggplot(data)         


The raw data that you want to visualise.




Aesthetics          


aes()


Aesthetic mappings between variables and visual properties..



Geometries


geom_*()


The geometric shapes representing the data.




Statistics


stat_*()


The statistical transformations applied to the data.




Scales


scale_*()


Maps between the data and the aesthetic dimensions.




Coordinate System


coord_*()


Maps data into the plane of the data rectangle.




Facets


facet_*()


The arrangement of the data into a grid of plots.




Visual Themes


theme() and theme_*()


The overall visual defaults of a plot.

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
The Data
Bike sharing counts in London, UK, powered by TfL Open Data


covers the years 2015 and 2016
incl. weather data acquired from freemeteo.com
prepared by Hristo Mavrodiev for Kaggle
further modification by myself





bikes <- readr::read_csv(
  "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/z3tt/graphic-design-ggplot2/main/data/london-bikes-custom.csv", 
  col_types = "Dcfffilllddddc"
)

bikes$season <- forcats::fct_inorder(bikes$season)

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text: ggplot2::ggplot()

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Data


ggplot(data = bikes)

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Aesthetic Mapping

= link variables to graphical properties


positions (x, y)
colors (color, fill)
shapes (shape, linetype)
size (size)
transparency (alpha)
groupings (group)

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Aesthetic Mapping


ggplot(data = bikes) +
  aes(x = temp_feel, y = count)

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
aesthetics
aes() outside as component

ggplot(data = bikes) + 
  aes(x = temp_feel, y = count)



aes() inside, explicit matching

ggplot(data = bikes, mapping = aes(x = temp_feel, y = count))




aes() inside, implicit matching

ggplot(bikes, aes(temp_feel, count))




aes() inside, mixed matching

ggplot(bikes, aes(x = temp_feel, y = count))

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Geometries

= interpret aesthetics as graphical representations


points
lines
polygons
text labels
…

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Geometries


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = temp_feel, y = count)
  ) +
  geom_point()

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Visual Properties of Layers


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = temp_feel, y = count)
  ) +
  geom_point(
    color = "#28a87d",
    alpha = .5,
    shape = "X",
    stroke = 1,
    size = 4
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
section: Setting vs Mapping of Visual Properties
text:
Setting vs Mapping of Visual Properties



ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = temp_feel, y = count)
  ) +
  geom_point(
    color = "#28a87d",
    alpha = .5
  )






ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = temp_feel, y = count)
  ) +
  geom_point(
    aes(color = season),
    alpha = .5
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Mapping Expressions


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = temp_feel, y = count)
  ) +
  geom_point(
    aes(color = temp_feel > 20),
    alpha = .5
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Quick Exercise


Create a scatter plot of temp_feel vs temp.

Map the color of the points to clear weather.
Map the size of the points to count.
Turn the points into diamonds.
Bonus: What do you notice in the legend? How could you fix it?






05:00

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Mapping Expressions


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = temp, y = temp_feel)
  ) +
  geom_point(
    aes(color = weather_type == "clear"),
    alpha = .5,
    size = 2
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Mapping to Size


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = temp, y = temp_feel)
  ) +
  geom_point(
    aes(color = weather_type == "clear",
        size = count),
    alpha = .5
  )

text:
Setting a Constant Property


ggplot(
    bikes,
    aes(x = temp, y = temp_feel)
  ) +
  geom_point(
    aes(color = weather_type == "clear",
        size = count),
    shape = 18,
    alpha = .5
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Setting a Constant Property


ggplot(
    bikes,
    aes(x = temp, y = temp_feel)
  ) +
  geom_point(
    aes(color = weather_type == "clear",
        size = count),
    shape = 5,
    alpha = .5
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Setting a Constant Property


ggplot(
    bikes,
    aes(x = temp, y = temp_feel)
  ) +
  geom_point(
    aes(color = weather_type == "clear",
        size = count),
    shape = 9,
    alpha = .5
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Setting a Constant Property


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = temp, y = temp_feel)
  ) +
  geom_point(
    aes(color = weather_type == "clear",
        size = count),
    shape = 23,
    alpha = .5
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Setting a Constant Property


ggplot(
    bikes,
    aes(x = temp, y = temp_feel)
  ) +
  geom_point(
    aes(fill = weather_type == "clear",
        size = count),
    shape = 23,
    color = "black",
    alpha = .5
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Filter Data


ggplot(
    filter(bikes, !is.na(weather_type)), 
    aes(x = temp, y = temp_feel)
  ) +
  geom_point(
    aes(color = weather_type == "clear",
        size = count),
    shape = 18,
    alpha = .5
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Filter Data


ggplot(
    bikes %>% filter(!is.na(weather_type)), 
    aes(x = temp, y = temp_feel)
  ) +
  geom_point(
    aes(color = weather_type == "clear",
        size = count),
    shape = 18,
    alpha = .5
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Local vs. Global Encoding



ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = temp_feel, y = count)
  ) +
  geom_point(
    aes(color = season),
    alpha = .5
  )






ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = temp_feel, y = count,
        color = season)
  ) +
  geom_point(
    alpha = .5
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Adding More Layers


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = temp_feel, y = count,
        color = season)
  ) +
  geom_point(
    alpha = .5
  ) +
  geom_smooth(
    method = "lm"
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Global Color Encoding


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = temp_feel, y = count,
        color = season)
  ) +
  geom_point(
    alpha = .5
  ) +
  geom_smooth(
    method = "lm"
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Local Color Encoding


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = temp_feel, y = count)
  ) +
  geom_point(
    aes(color = season),
    alpha = .5
  ) +
  geom_smooth(
    method = "lm"
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
The `group` Aesthetic


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = temp_feel, y = count)
  ) +
  geom_point(
    aes(color = season),
    alpha = .5
  ) +
  geom_smooth(
    aes(group = day_night),
    method = "lm"
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Set Both as Global Aesthetics


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = temp_feel, y = count,
        color = season,
        group = day_night)
  ) +
  geom_point(
    alpha = .5
  ) +
  geom_smooth(
    method = "lm"
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Overwrite Global Aesthetics


ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = temp_feel, y = count,
        color = season,
        group = day_night)
  ) +
  geom_point(
    alpha = .5
  ) +
  geom_smooth(
    method = "lm",
    color = "black"
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Store a ggplot as Object

g <- 
  ggplot(
    bikes, 
    aes(x = temp_feel, y = count,
        color = season,
        group = day_night)
  ) +
  geom_point(
    alpha = .5
  ) +
  geom_smooth(
    method = "lm",
    color = "black"
  )

class(g)

[1] "gg"     "ggplot"

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Inspect a ggplot Object

g$data

 4 2015-01-05 night     2015  1     winter  5609 TRUE       FALSE

 6 2015-01-06 night     2015  1     winter  6112 TRUE       FALSE

 9 2015-01-08 day       2015  1     winter  9971 TRUE       FALSE     
10 2015-01-08 night     2015  1     winter  5630 TRUE       FALSE     
# … with 1,444 more rows, and 6 more variables: is_holiday <lgl>, temp <dbl>,
#   temp_feel <dbl>, humidity <dbl>, wind_speed <dbl>, weather_type <chr>

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Inspect a ggplot Object

g$mapping

Aesthetic mapping: 
* `x`      -> `temp_feel`
* `y`      -> `count`
* `colour` -> `season`
* `group`  -> `day_night`

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
section: Extend a ggplot Object: Add Layers
text:
Extend a ggplot Object: Add Layers


g +
  geom_rug(
    alpha = .2
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
section: Remove a Layer from the Legend
text:
Remove a Layer from the Legend


g +
  geom_rug(
    alpha = .2,
    show.legend = FALSE
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
section: Extend a ggplot Object: Add Labels
text:
Extend a ggplot Object: Add Labels


g +
  xlab("Feels-like temperature (°F)") +
  ylab("Reported bike shares") +
  ggtitle("TfL bike sharing trends")

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
section: Extend a ggplot Object: Add Labels
text:
Extend a ggplot Object: Add Labels


g +
  labs(
    x = "Feels-like temperature (°F)",
    y = "Reported bike shares",
    title = "TfL bike sharing trends"
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
section: Extend a ggplot Object: Add Labels
text:
Extend a ggplot Object: Add Labels


g <- g +
  labs(
    x = "Feels-like temperature (°F)",
    y = "Reported bike shares",
    title = "TfL bike sharing trends",
    color = "Season:"
  )

g

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
section: Extend a ggplot Object: Add Labels
text:
Extend a ggplot Object: Add Labels


g +
  labs(
    x = "Feels-like temperature (°F)",
    y = "Reported bike shares",
    title = "TfL bike sharing trends",
    subtitle = "Reported bike rents versus feels-like temperature in London",
    caption = "Data: TfL",
    color = "Season:",
    tag = "Fig. 1"
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
section: Extend a ggplot Object: Add Labels
text:
Extend a ggplot Object: Add Labels



g +
  labs(
    x = "",
    caption = "Data: TfL"
  )





g +
  labs(
    x = NULL,
    caption = "Data: TfL"
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Extend a ggplot Object: Themes



g + theme_light()






g + theme_minimal()

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Change the Theme Base Settings


g + theme_light(
  base_size = 14,
  base_family = "Roboto Condensed"
)

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Set a Theme Globally


theme_set(theme_light())

g

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Change the Theme Base Settings


theme_set(theme_light(
  base_size = 14,
  base_family = "Roboto Condensed"
))

g

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Overwrite Specific Theme Settings


g +
  theme(
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Overwrite Specific Theme Settings


g +
  theme(
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold")
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Overwrite Specific Theme Settings


g +
  theme(
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"),
    legend.position = "top"
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Overwrite Specific Theme Settings


g +
  theme(
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"),
    legend.position = "top",
    plot.title.position = "plot"
  )

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Overwrite Theme Settings Globally


theme_update(
  panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
  plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"),
  legend.position = "top",
  plot.title.position = "plot"
)

g

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Save the Graphic

ggsave(g, filename = "my_plot.png")



ggsave("my_plot.png")




ggsave("my_plot.png", width = 8, height = 5, dpi = 600)




ggsave("my_plot.pdf", width = 20, height = 12, unit = "cm", device = cairo_pdf)




grDevices::cairo_pdf("my_plot.pdf", width = 10, height = 7)
g
dev.off()

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
section: How to Work with Aspect Ratios
text:
How to Work with Aspect Ratios


don’t rely on the Rstudio viewer pane!
once you have a “it’s getting close” prototype, settle on a plot size
Approach 1: save the file to disk and inspect it; go back to your IDE

tedious and time-consuming…

Approach 2: use a qmd or rmd with inline output and chunk settings

set fig.width and fig.height per chunk or globally

Approach 3: use our {camcorder} package

saves output from all ggplot() calls and displays it in the viewer pane

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text: Setting Plot Sizes in Rmd’s

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text: Setting Plot Sizes via {camcorder}

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Recap



{ggplot2} is a powerful library for reproducible graphic design
the components follow a consistent syntax
each ggplot needs at least data, some aesthetics, and a layer
we set constant propeties outside aes()
… and map data-related properties inside aes()
local settings and mappings override global properties
grouping allows applying layers for subsets
we can store a ggplot object and extend it afterwards
we can change the appearance for all plots with theme_set() and theme_update()

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Your Turn!

Open the script 02_concepts_pt1_ex1.Rmd.



Cédric Scherer // rstudio::conf // July 2022

title: Resources

Textbooks

Introduction to Modern Statistics by Mine Çetinkaya-Rundel and Johanna Hardin

title: Resources
text:
Papers


Designing introductory data science curricula:

Çetinkaya-Rundel, M., & Ellison, V. (2021). A fresh look at introductory data science. Journal of Statistics and Data Science Education, 29(sup1), S16-S26. https://doi.org/10.1080/10691898.2020.1804497.
Baumer, B. (2015). A data science course for undergraduates: Thinking with data. The American Statistician, 69(4), 334-342. https://doi.org/10.1080/00031305.2015.1081105.

Teaching reproducibility and version control:

Beckman, M. D., Çetinkaya-Rundel, M., Horton, N. J., Rundel, C. W., Sullivan, A. J., & Tackett, M. (2021). Implementing version control with Git and GitHub as a learning objective in statistics and data science courses. Journal of Statistics and Data Science Education, 29(sup1), S132-S144. https://doi.org/10.1080/10691898.2020.1848485.

Teaching with the tidyverse:

Çetinkaya-Rundel, M., Hardin, J., Baumer, B., McNamara, A., Horton, N., & Rundel, C. (2022). An educator’s perspective of the tidyverse. Technology Innovations in Statistics Education, 14(1). http://dx.doi.org/10.5070/T514154352.

Organizing teaching materials:

Dogucu, M., & Çetinkaya-Rundel, M. (2022). Tools and Recommendations for Reproducible Teaching. arXiv preprint arXiv:2202.09504. https://doi.org/10.48550/arXiv.2202.09504.

Teaching modern modeling:

Tackett, M. (2022) Three principles for modernizing an undergraduate regression analysis course. arXiv preprint arXiv:2205.11026. https://doi.org/10.48550/arXiv.2205.11026

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text: 🗓️ July 25 and 26, 2022 ⏰ 09:00 - 17:00 🏨 [ADD ROOM] ✍️ rstd.io/conf

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Overview
Creating engaging and accessible data visualizations of high quality in an efficient and preferably reproducible way is an essential tool in a data scientist’s toolbox. After completing the course, participants will have a solid understanding of data visualization principles and the functionality of the ggplot2 graphics library and helpful extension libraries to create highly customized graphics without the need for post-processing.
We will discuss the main concepts of the grammar of graphics and use hands-on examples to explore ggplot2’s utility to create multi-layered, more complex graphs. The workshop covers a short overview of the basics of ggplot2 and quickly focuses on the most important steps and helpful tips to create visually appealing and complex graphics both in theory and practice. The power of ggplot2 will be illustrated with advanced real–life examples that help to understand data visualization principles and useful coding tricks.
The course covers complex code examples that are suited for more experienced ggplot2 users but designed to be informative for participants with minimal prior experience in ggplot2 and data visualization. As part of the training, attendees can download the course material from the course webpage for future reference.

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Learning objectives

Understanding the general concepts of ggplot2.
Learning the many options of customizing a ggplot.
Gaining the major steps need to create engaging graphics.
Being able to generate complex plots without th need of post-processing.

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Is this course for me?
This course will be appropriate for you if you answer yes to these questions:

Do you aim to build graphics in a fully reproducible way without the need to manually adjust details afterwards?
Do you enjoy using the {ggplot2} package but are interested in doing more with it?
Would you like to learn how to improve future data visualizations in terms of accessibility, impact, and complexity?

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Prework
The workshop will also cover the basic logic of ggplot2 and its compontents. However, some pre-knowledge on how the package works is beneficial for following the examples and for the group exercises. A good overview is provided might by the “First Steps” chapter of the ggplot2 book by Hadley Wickham et al.: https://ggplot2-book.org/getting-started.html

title: Graphic Design with ggplot2
text:
Requirements
The example codes and the hands-on workshop parts are run in the Rstudio cloud. Thus, nothing but a laptop is needed. If you want to follow the workshop locally, please make sure to install a suitable IDE (Rstudio, VS Code or others), a recent version of R (4.1+) and the following packages (to be extended):

{tidyverse} and related
{ggplot2}, {readr}, {tibble}, {tidyr}, {dplyr}, {forcats}, {stringr}, {lubridate},


{ggplot2} extensions
{ggtext}, {ggrepel}, {ggforce}, {ggdist}, {ggalt}, {ggridges}, {patchwork}


Color palettes
{RColorBrewer}, {scico}, {rcartocolor}


Misc
{magick}, {systemfonts}
For Mac OS users: Please make sure that XQuartz is installed which is needed to use the cairo pdf device.
